titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VII:30. Friday— Before the meeting of the House this morning, I asked Mr Beardsley, a member from New-York, to expostulate with his colleague Hoffman, against his avowed purpose to talk out the remainder of the Session to prevent the printing of my Minority Report of the Committee of Manufactures, and to tell him he must allow me time to reply, and the House, time to take the Question— Beardsley spoke to him, and he agreed to take the question by yeas and nays, without saying any thing further on either side— When the Report was called up, I stated this agreement to the House, to which Hoffman assented. John S. Barbour said there was not perhaps in the whole Report a Sentiment with which he concurred; but that he should vote for the printing as a right of the Minority. The question was taken by yeas and nays, and the printing was carried 93 to 58. about 50 members not voting. There was a Report from the Majority of the Committee of Ways and Means, favourable to the Bank of the United States, concluding with a Resolution that the public funds, may be safely deposited
in it—and a Counter-report made by Polk for the Minority, with a budget of Documents. Ten thousand copies of both were ordered to be printed— The Question upon the passage of the Revenue collection-bill was taken by yeas and nays 149 to 48. M’Duffie moved an Amendment of the Title—to read—[“]An Act to subvert the Sovereignty of the States of this Union, to establish a consolidated Government, without limitation of powers, and to make the civil subordinate to the Military power” Wayne moved to lay the amendment on the Table; but the Speaker declared this to be not in order— Speight moved the previous Question, which was carried 150 to 35, and set aside M’Duffies’s Amendment. The subsequent orders of the day were then postponed to take up Mr Clay’s Bill for distributing the proceeds of the Public Lands. The House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Polk in the Chair: the bill was debated captiously by C. C. Clay, Mardis and Plummer from Alabama and Mississippi. Plummer was especially tedious and provoking— About 11. at Night the Bill was reported to the House and driven to the 3d reading by previous Questions. It passed by yeas and nays 96 to 40. Then the Harbour and Light-house bill was for some time considered, laid aside and followed by the general Appropriation Bill. After which a Bill authorising the President to appoint a clerk to sign his name to Land Warrants was agreed to. The Bills were reported to the House, which then, sometime after one in the Morning, adjourned. The Session had continued little short of fifteen hours, without a recess. Yesterday and this day there have been large falls of Snow, and severer cold than during any part of the winter— Potowmac frozen over.

2. VII:30. Saturday.— The first business taken up by the House was the Resolution reported by the Majority of the Committee of Ways and Means that the Public funds may safely continue to be deposited in the Bank of the United States, against which Polk of Tennessee made a violent Speech. He was answered by Ingersoll, and afterwards by M’Duffie. The previous Question was moved, and although Wayne of Georgia pleaded hard to speak was carried, and the Resolution was adopted 110 to 46. Wayne voted against it, upon which I condoled with him. He was mortified to be compelled to give such a vote, and afterwards read to me a Letter that he had written to a friend saying that his vote was not owing to any doubt of the solvency of the Bank, but because the withdrawal of the Public Deposites was a discretionary power given by Law to the Secretary of the Treasury, and he would not divide with him the responsibility— Wayne said that was ground which I had taken at the commencement of the Session, which was true—but that was before the investigation referred by the House to the Committee of Ways and Means, and against the appointment of a select Committee. The General Appropriation Bill was taken up and debated till four O’Clock, and then by the previous Question, ordered to be engrossed for a third reading. There was a recess from 4 to 6 O’Clock. I went and dined again with Thomas Newton at his lodgings. Clement C. Dorsey was among the fellow lodgers there. At 6 we returned to the House. The Appropriation Bills were passed, and sent to the Senate, who had half a Night to consider and pass them— The House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and hurried through an Indian-Treaty Bill. The Bill to explain the 18th. Section of the Act of 14 July 1832— The Hard-ware Bill, upon which at my motion was engrafted as an additional Section, a Bill from the Senate, restoring duties upon Brass, copper, and tobacco in leaves, which being a Bill to raise revenue could not constitutionally originate in the Senate and the Light house Bill, upon which there was much wrangling. The House sat till five O’Clock Sunday morning. The President retained the Land-bill without signing it. Felix Grundy stopped the Light-House Bill in the Senate, by objecting to its being read the second time on the same day. Howard of Baltimore moved the vote of thanks to Stevenson, which was entered as passed unanimously, though when he came to the word impartiality, there was a burst of laughter in the House. About two O’Clock in the Morning, Chittenden Lyon of Kentucky, drunk as a Lord, presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky, which he said he had just
received, and which he moved to be laid on the Table and printed— On being asked what was the subject of the Resolutions, he drivelled out “Nullification.” Almost every quarter of an hour after Midnight, business was suspended for want of a Quorum— Shortly before 3. O’Clock, Whittlesey of Ohio prevailed upon the House to go again into Committee of the whole. There was a call of the House and 116. members answered to their names— Several private Bills passed through the Committee, were reported to the House and passed— About 4. Sevier, the Delegate from Arkansas moved and urged the house to go into Committee of the whole, upon three important territorial Bills, but on taking the question only 90 members answered— Of course 26 had withdrawn, since the call, half an hour before— A Message was received from the Senate, that they had appointed a Committee to wait on the President, and inform him that unless he had further communications to make to Congress, the Houses were ready to adjourn. Campbell P. White of New-York, and Polk of Tennessee were appointed the Committee on the part of the House. They soon returned and announced that the President had no further communications to make. Stevenson, the Speaker, made a silly Speech, in return for the vote of thanks, and adjourned the House without day— The hands of the Clock were pointing, at five, as we passed under them out of the Hall. I took Edward Everett home, and we were in imminent danger of oversetting in the midst of the Pennsylvania Avenue, nearly opposite to Gadsby’s. We got out of the Carriage—Kirk was asleep, and the horses had stopped. I ordered Ball to take the reins; we re-entered the Carriage and got into the Macadamized part of the Avenue— On reaching Mr Everett’s lodgings, I alighted with him, and thence walked home, with Fahrenheit’s Thermometer at 6. the extremest cold of the winter, and the ground covered with snow. The day was dawning and I retired to bed, exhausted and dejected, but with blessings of gratitude to the Supreme disposer of Events, for the merciful dispensations of his Providence, in bringing the affairs of the Country to a condition more favourable to Peace and Union than it has been of late, and though still surrounded with dangers— And also in the disposal of my own destiny for conducting me through the severe and humiliating trial, which I have endured, without absolute and irretrievable ruin— My Career is yet to be closed. It is in its last and lingering Stage— May its remaining afflictions be mitigated— May its last moments be serene— May its transition be to a happier state of existence.
3. IX. Sunday.

After three hours of repose, but not of sleep, I rose and at 11. attended public worship, at the Presbyterian Church—where I heard Mr Smith’s second Discourse from Romans 8.7.—it seemed to me a repetition of the first— Mr Hassler was here after the morning Service, and said much about the Survey of the Coast— I was not in a humour to talk, but that is in no wise necessary when Mr Hassler is allowed to talk without interruption— In the afternoon I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read part of the Evening prayer, for the Second Sunday in Lent, and gave a very short exposition of 2. Corinthians 6.16. “for ye are the temple of the living God.[”] I received evening visits from Joseph Blunt, from George M. Briggs, a member of the late House from Berkshire, Massachusetts, and from Heman Allen of Vermont. I was disqualified for all proper application even to the duties of the day; which, I believe with more real piety, might have been devoted to the performance of that, which in extreme disorder and confusion was transacted, between Midnight and five this morning. I prefer the example of Sunday 3 March 1805. when both Houses of Congress sat from 9 in the morning, till 10 at Night, to that of this day, the scruples of which are all in the bark.
4. VIII. Monday.

My health is wretched, and I know not all my disease. I consulted Dr Huntt this morning and he prescribed a blister on my arm. I have now an inflammation coming in the eye— Andrew Jackson was this day inaugurated for a second term of four years as President of the United States; and Martin van Buren was sworn into Office as Vice-President. Mr John Sergeant called here. He had attended the ceremony at the Capitol. The inaugural Speech was brief, and full of smooth professions. Sergeant himself was the Candidate for Vice-Presidency of the National Republican Opposition— Henry Clay was their Candidate for the Presidency— They mustered 49 electoral votes, with the help of Massachusetts federalism. Had Mr Clay been unshackled with Freemasonry, or manfully renounced it they would in all probability have carried the Election— William Haworth is an Englishman and an Astrologer. He brought me a Letter of Introduction from Thomas Hulme of Philadelphia. He says he is a firm believer in Providence, but a believer also in the influence of the Stars, and in Magic— He was here about two hours, talking about the Signs of the Zodiac and the Houses of the Horoscope. The stuff that dreams are made of. He said he would come again to-morrow. Mr Mitchell of South-Carolina came in while he was here and he went away— Mitchell wants some Evidence that the Manufacturers are pleased with Mr Clay’s Tariff-Bill, because that would enable him to make it odious in South-Carolina. The President had a crowded Levee after the inauguration, but was so unwell that he was obliged to leave his company and retire.
5. VII.30. Tuesday

The inflammation in my left eye is increasing. Stokes was here, and I gave him a copy of his Uncle’s Will, which Mr William B. Shepherd had procured for him and given last week to me. He wanted his own papers which I have mislaid, but am to look up. Billings the tax-collector brought me two heavy tax-bills, one for myself, and one for my Son John— Haworth the Astrologer was here again and shewed me his Manuscript-Books of horoscopes— His calculations of Eclipses, Conjunctions and oppositions of Planets, and ascendant signs of the Zodiac. He says there will be trouble in South-Carolina, because there will be a total Eclipse of the Sun there in 1834. An argument as rational as nullification— I wished to know what his theory of Astrology was; but I find it will take too much time to study it— I wanted to compare it with Phrenology. Mr Ayres was also here. Very anxious to know my opinion about Mr Thompson of Nashville’s system for teaching the blind to read; and about his diplomatic cypher. I called at the Bank, and walked to the Capitol. In the Supreme Court of the United States, I found Chapman Johnson of Virginia arguing a Chancery suit of King vs White; upon fraudulent Conveyance, Maintenance, and Champarty.— We had a family party and others to dine with us.
6. VIII. Wednesday.

The inflammation of my eye was disqualifying, and disheartening— Edward Everett was here; going to-morrow for home— He spoke to me of a purpose concerning which his brother had written to him—to unite the National Republicans and the Anti-Masons of Massachusetts upon me as a Candidate for the Office of Governor the next year, Mr Lincoln having declined. Hallett has written to me on the same subject— I told Everett that I should much prefer to come again to the House of Representatives— That I was unwilling to involve myself in the Tracasseries of State Politics; and that I believed the Masonic National Republicans too much exasperated against me for my Anti-masonry to unite with the Anti-masons in supporting me— That if it could
effect the union of those parties, I might consent to serve for a single year, though I had firmly resolved that I never would accept that Office, having been all my life, with the exception of a single year in the Senate of Massachusetts, in the Public Service of the whole Union. The minority Report of the Committee of Manufactures, not being published, I wrote a Note to Duff Green, the Public Printer, enquiring if he had put it to the Press.— He promised me last Friday that he would print it immediately; and that he would also publish it in his Extra Telegraph— I received this Evening an answer from his foreman, W. W. Moore to my Note, informing me that it has not been put to the Press.

7. VII. Thursday.— I had a small blister last Night applied to my arm just below the shoulder, and this day the inflammation of my eye has begun to subside— But I am still in a great measure unable to resume my usual occupations. My Diary, and especially my scriptural Notes run into arrears— Finding Mr Duff Green, the Printer for Congress in no hurry to print the Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures, I wrote him a note asking the Manuscript for a few days, and he sent it to me. I took it to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and left it with Mr Gales, who promised me that it should be published entire in the Intelligencer of next Tuesday. I then walked to the Capitol, but the Supreme Court had adjourned. Mr Chapman Johnson had closed his argument, and was to be answered by Walter Jones, and afterwards by Mr Webster— Mr Calhoun’s Speech of 15. February upon the enforcement bill, is published in the Telegraph— It contains his system of nullification. His learning is shallow— His mind, argumentative, and his assumption of the principle, destitute of discernment. His insanity begins with his principles; from which his deductions are ingeniously drawn— I read this Evening the first Canto of Rose’s Translation of Ariosto’s Orlando-furioso.

8. Friday. VI. Recovering from the inflammation in my eye, my endeavours are to return to my routine of occupations, and particularly to my Diary and morning writing— Also to the assortment of my papers, which absorbed great part of this morning, and was yet left unfinished. I am especially desirous of reviewing the Code of Levitical Law; and of examining it as a system of Legislation— This task has long been in my contemplation; but I have never yet settled the principles upon which it should be executed— The History—the Legislation and the Government of the Israelites are so blended together that it is no easy matter to segregate them, as must be done for a clear analysis. The Religion, Laws and Government, were indissolubly connected together— The different Offices of Moses, Joshua, the Levites and Priests, the Judges, Seers, Prophets and Kings— The subordinate administrative Offices— The force of the Scriptures, of the Psalms, Proverbs, Prophecies, and numberless other considerations— How are they to be methodized? I am to reflect upon this Subject further— I walked to the Capitol, with a hope to hear Mr Webster, but was disappointed— The Supreme Court had adjourned. W. Ellis of Dedham has sent me a fragment of an old pamphlet published in January or February 1809. during the Embargo— A defence of Mr Jefferson’s administration— He thinks it was written by W. B. Giles, but is mistaken.
9. V:30. Saturday.

Assorting still my papers. Wrote an answer to a Letter some days since received from Benjamin F. Hallett, Editor of the Boston Daily Advocate.— The weather is very fine, and the Snow which had fallen is gradually disappearing— I walked to the Capitol, where in the Supreme Court I found Mr Clay and Mr Webster arguing the two sides of a writ of Error, from a Court in Louisiana— Dry as dust— And the eloquence of the Champions could
not make it otherwise— I spoke to Mr Webster and told him I wished to have some conversation with him, before he leaves the city—he promised to call upon me— In the evening I had visits from General Macomb, who told me that he had given a furlough for Robert Buchanan, for three Months, because he did not like long leaves of absence; but that he would extend it when Robert should be here. Blunt is going to-morrow for New-York— He asked me for a Chapter, for the next Volume of his American Annual Register; but it is impossible for me to furnish one. I received from the National Intelligencer Office the proof sheets of the Minority Manufacture Report, and was employed all the Evening revising it.
10. VI:30. Sunday.

I heard Mr Smith’s third, and I suppose last Discourse, of the Series upon Romans 8.7. “Because the carnal mind, is enmity against God: for it is not subject to the Law of God, neither indeed can be”— He made a very solemn appeal to Sinners, of whom he thought there were some among his hearers— After Church I had a visit from Mr Daniel Brent— And I returned the visits of Chief Justice Marshall and Judge Story. Judge Thompson was also there— They engaged me in conversation, till it was near 4 O’Clock before I returned home to dinner— I then went to Mr Laurie’s Church and heard an Address from a Mr Bard, in behalf of the Establishment of Sunday Schools in the Valley of the Mississippi for which a Collection was taken up— There was no afternoon Service either at Mr Smith’s, or at St. John’s Church— Mr Bard made some extraordinary Statements, respecting the destitution of Common Schools in the Western States, excepting Ohio. The numbers of People who can neither write nor read in the other Western States and Territories is surprizing. I finished the revisal of the Minority Report, and sent it back to the Office of the National Intelligencer. I read also two Chapters in Gleig’s History of the Bible. My Sunday reading has been much neglected during the last Winter.
11. V. Monday.

I am endeavouring to resume my habits of industry, and employed a due portion of this day in writing. First, making an abstract of the Law, as contained in the Book of Deuteronomy— After breakfast, I looked up some of the Letters upon Pensions and other claims, to which I was unable to attend during the Session of Congress. Made abstracts of four of them, upon which I applied for three to the Secretary of War, and for one to the Secretary of the Navy. They were the cases of Benjamin Bates, of Caleb Hayden, and of William Donnison for Pensions, and for the widow of Liliston Banks, for prize-money. The Secretaries promised immediate attention to them. Mr Cass had a Charleston Mercury, in which Mr Clay’s Tariff-Bill was mentioned as having set aside the nullifying Ordinance, and the opinion is expressed that the Convention would not pass another. It spoke of the enforcing Bill as a mere effusion of Spleen, on the part of the Administration, of which South-Carolina would take no notice. I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer to enquire for the Manuscript of the Minority Report of the Committee of Manufactures, and also whether any copies of the Report were yet struck off. I had sent them back the proof revised last Evening— I afterwards met both Gales and Seaton, and Gales promised to send me the Manuscript this Evening, and several copies of the Paper in time to forward them by the mail, but he did not. I met General Root of New-York, just going to the Stage upon his return home. His Son in Law Hobbie was with him. I took leave of Root, probably for the last time. I met also Mr Burges of Rhode-Island, who told me he was going to-morrow. He had sent me his Speech against Mr Clay’s Tariff-Bill, and his reply to Daniel. He said he had been much urged not to publish them, but he would not keep from the Public what he had said and what he thought. It was Calhoun’s Bill; and its first effect must be to reduce the wages of the labourers in the Manufactures, and to drive them to emigrate to the West— I walked to the Capitol—called at the Clerk’s office of the House of Representatives, and enquired for the
Documents of the Session of Congress before the last— He said he had just received them, and would send me a set. I went into the Supreme Court and found Walter Jones, arguing the cause upon which I had heard Chapman Johnson last week on the other side. Jones had not finished when the Court adjourned. I had an evening visit from Mr Rush, who has come down from York, Pennsylvania, on his private business— Began a Letter to my Son Charles.
12. V. Tuesday.

The analysis of the Law from Sinai, occupied this morning with the Diary of yesterday till Breakfast— The Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures, was published in the National Intelligencer of this day. 17 Columns— Visit from Mr David Hoffman of Baltimore. He is going to Europe, and had written to me, asking Letters of introduction— I apologized to him for having delayed to answer him and told him that I had not an acquaintance in Europe left to whom I could give him a Letter. He asked me for a pamphlet copy of the Minority Report, which I promised him. I found a Letter from Zaccheus Bartlett of Plymouth, with a list of claimants for pensions, concerning whose claims he desired me to obtain information— I took the list to the War Department, and left it with the Secretary Cass— Then went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and received from Mr Gales the Manuscript of the Report. He sent me forty copies of the Newspaper, containing its part of which I distributed to some of my friends, despatching them by this Evenings mail— This document is an appeal to the People, I fear a vain and fruitless one, against the system of Government promulged in the last annual presidential Message. leading to the dissolution of the Union. I passed an hour at the Supreme Court, where Walter Jones closed and Mr Webster began the argument in answer to Chapman Johnson.
13. V. Wednesday.

Mr Ayres was here this morning, and explained to me the system of William Thompson, of Nashville Tennessee, for teaching the blind to read Also his two systems of cryptography or cypher writing. They are all ingenious, and there are certificates of the successful use of the mode of teaching the blind. He told me that Mr Michael Hoffman, had recommended it to the Governor of New-York— The cyphers have the inconvenience of all cyphers that I ever saw—they must consume much time, either to write or read— Mr Rush spent an hour with me this morning, and John W Taylor this afternoon.— Mr Rush spoke of the recent Anti-masonic convention, on the 4th at Harrisburg, as having been very respectable, and he is sanguine in expecting the final success of the cause in Pennsylvania. Taylor is going for home to-morrow. He has been twenty years successively a member of Congress but is now left out. His circumstances are straitened, with a family of five Sons and three daughters, and he has thoughts of selling out his small property, and removing to one of the Southwestern States— After returning home, he will go to Albany, and if any thing of interest should occur, will write to me— In my walk round the Capitol, I was overtaken by Chief Justice Marshall and judge Story.

14. V. Thursday— I finished a Letter, begun three days ago, to my Son Charles and revised the copy of the Minority Report of Manufactures printed in the National Intelligencer of last Tuesday, which I sent with the Manuscript to Duff Green the Public Printer. I walked to the Capitol, and heard Mr Wirt about an hour, concluding the argument in the case of King and White, the Chancery cause, upon which I had heard Mr Chapman Johnson— I took with me notes of invitation to the judges to dine with me next Saturday, but the Court is to adjourn to-morrow. Judge Story is already gone, and all the others intend to take their departure on Saturday.— Returning home I stopped at Mr Webster’s lodgings, and invited him to dine with me on Saturday, which he promised— He was despatching copies of his Speech in reply to J. C. Calhoun, published in this morning’s Intelligencer.
I had some conversation with him, and he promised to call and see me to-morrow. John W. Taylor had spoken to me of his conversation, with Mr Webster, and with judge M’lean, who he says thinks of nothing but the Presidency by day, and dreams of nothing else by night. Mr Webster was not very communicative to me. I read the third Canto of Rose’s Ariosto. A very dull genealogical catalogue of the family of Cardinal Hippolito d’Este the Poet’s Patron.
15. V. Friday.

Mr Gales came this morning with the manuscript notes of the Reporter of the Telegraph, of Coll Drayton’s Speech in answer to mine on Verplanck’s Tariff-Bill— That, and my reply, he will publish to-morrow. But Drayton has altered so much, in revising the Notes of the Reporter that Gales enquired whether he should not take notice of it by some note, Editorial, or written by me. I supposed some note would be proper, but left it to him to make it. Mr Stokes came, and I returned his papers that he had left with me. An old man, named Whiting, now an applicant for a Pension, called to see me. He said the last time he had seen me, was at the Dedham Court of Sessions in 1806. He then lived at Franklin and was born at Medway. He removed to Philadelphia in 1808. and has lived there ever since. Judge Thompson called, and promised to dine with me to-morrow— I walked round the Capitol before dinner. In the afternoon, Mr Webster came, and I had a long conversation with him upon Public affairs. He thinks it doubtful, whether Edward Livingston will go to France this year. He himself will visit the State of Ohio next Summer— A boy from the National Intelligencer Office, brought me the proof of my Speech, to be published in the paper to-morrow morning; but I had not time to revise it. Received papers from the War Department.
16. V:30 Saturday.

My morning scriptural readings and comments occupy more and more of my time. To read the Bible usefully, there should always some annotation made upon the portion of it daily read— My second Speech upon Verplanck’s Tariff-Bill is in the Intelligencer of this Morning— Walking round the Capitol Hill this day before dinner, I met Thomas R. Mitchell of South Carolina, who told me he was remaining here writing a Circular to his Constituents. I read the fifth Canto of Rose’s Ariosto, containing the story told by Dalinda, of her own amour with the Duke of Albany—the false charge against Genevra daughter to the king of Scotland, which it occasioned, and the duel in which the accuser Polinesso is slain by Rinaldo,— It is the same Story with that of Shakespear’s Much Ado About Nothing— Rose’s humour is not so pungent as that of Byron in his version from Pulci’s Morgante Maggiore. The Serio-comic is not so well mingled. We had the company named in the margin to dine with us, and much mirth and good humour. Mr Rush remained half an hour after the rest had retired. His attempt to sell his House at Auction this day failed. No bid above 6500. I had a morning visit from Mr Van Buren and his Son Abraham.

17. IV:30. Sunday— Heard Mr Smith this Morning at the Presbyterian Church. His fourth Sermon upon Romans 8.7. the carnal mind enmity against God. I had thought his morning Discourse of last Sunday would have been the last upon this text— I heard nothing this day but what appeared to me to be repetition of the same thing he had said before— After dinner at St John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for the fourth Sunday in Lent. He read the whole Service, and preached from Solomon’s Song 5:16. “This is my beloved, and this is my friend.” Christ and his Church. It was a remnant of his mornings discourse. I employed all the leisure of the day, in scriptural readings and notices. Read two Chapters in Gleig’s History
of the Bible, and one Book of Milman’s History of the Jews. The latter appears to be the most philosophical— Milman notices the three several promises of God to Abraham of the land of Canaan. The last solemnized by the remarkable sacrifice and Covenant of Genesis 15.9–18.— The animals sacrificed were a heifer, a she-goat, a ram, a turtle-dove and a young pigeon— These were all the animals afterwards used to be sacrificed. Milman further says that Teraphim were so called, as images first made by Terah, the father of Abraham.
18. IV:45. Monday

Morning occupied in commenting upon the passages of Scripture that I have been reading and upon the map of Palestine in Milman’s History of the Jews. Mr Rush called upon me, and read to me two or three paragraphs of a Letter that he had received from Mr Ellmaker’s complimentary to my Speech on Verplanck’s Tariff-Bill, and enquiring for the Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures. I gave Mr Rush two copies of it.— I had also much conversation with him upon the subject of Masonry and Anti-Masonry. He urges me particularly to write upon the subserviency of the periodical Press to the controul of Masonry. But I think there is nothing, or very little to add upon that topic, to what has been published by him. There are perhaps other views of the general subject yet to be taken. I walked before dinner to the Race-ground and back. This walk which brings me in view of Meridian Hill, and of the Columbian College awakens recollections of bitterness and melancholy mingled with some soothing consolations— My residence of three Months at Meridian Hill was marked with two of the heaviest calamities with which my life has been visited— Read the 6th. Canto of Rose’s Ariosto— It is irremissibly dull.

19. IV:15. Tuesday.— I had a visitor with a subscription paper to build a Church for a German Preacher, to which I declined putting my name. There are a number of Germans who arrived in this Country, perhaps last Summer, and are now employed in pounding up the stone, for M’Adamizing the Pennsylvania Avenue. The project of a Church is for them; but if erected they would not be able to maintain it— I went to the War Office— The Secretary was absent at a Cabinet-Meeting— I went to the Pension Office, and asked Mr Edwards, the Commissioner of Pensions, for answers upon two of the cases which I had exhibited before, and which had been overlooked— I also left with him the papers of Elisha James, upon which he promised to send me an answer to-morrow Morning— I walked and partly rode to the Capitol, and took out of the Library all the remaining Volumes of Rose’s version of the Orlando Furioso. Of which I read after dinner the seventh Canto. There is no appearance of the Hero yet. Nor is it possible in the seven Canto’s that I have read to perceive any plan, or unity of action. It seems to be a collection of Fairy Tales, without connection between them. The enchantment of Alcina, and its decantation in this seventh Canto, are full of beauties of detail. The horses and Swords of the Knights have their names.
20. VI:15. Wednesday.

After waking this morning at three O’Clock, I fell into another nap, and was belated till past six before I rose. The little annotations that I make upon my morning reading of the Scriptures lead me into enquiries beyond my depth, like wading into the shelving banks of a river, till the foot can no longer touch the bottom. I recur to Gleig and Milman, but above all want better maps of the holy Land— Mr James Bayard of Philadelphia came to enquire if I had any recollection of the case of a Barque called the Superior, lost in the passage of the Belt in October 1809. concerning which I made an application to the Danish Government through Baron Blome 12/24 January 1810. There is now
an application for indemnity, in behalf of the owners of that vessel and Cargo, before the Danish Commission— The vessel was with British ships of War, but not under their convoy. She struck upon a rock, and was fired upon from the shore. The master set fire to her by order of the Commander of the British Squadron— Part of the Cargo was said to have been saved as wreck by the People on the Land. Mr Bayard had a copy of my note to Baron Blome; but I had no other recollection of the case. It cannot be received as a claim for property seized, for it was destroyed by the Master himself— Rain all day— I only walked before and after dinner round the square fronting the house.

21. IV. Thursday.— Walk round Capitol hill; wrote 3 short Letters— As I proceed in my morning notes I find the want of scriptural Geography increasing— I made a rough sketch from the map, of Milman’s History, shewing merely the relative location of the twelve tribes in the Land of Canaan, on both sides of the river Jordan— I dined at General Macomb’s, with a motley mixture of company. Mr Van Buren the Vice-President; Mr Woodbury, Secretary of the Navy—Mr Rush, with General Mason, and his Son, John: Mr Donaldson, the Presidents private Secretary; Mr Campbell, the Treasurer— Messrs. Torlade, Chargé d’Affaires from Don Miguel of Portugal, Ankarloo from Sweden, Krehmer, from Russia, two or three Officers, and three Ladies, besides Mrs and Miss Macomb— I had much conversation with Mr Campbell, the Treasurer, whose acquaintance I made at Table, and some with Mr Ankarloo, whom I had not met before; also with Mr Woodbury on the weather and other matters equally interesting after dinner. Mr Rush gave me a Pennsylvania Newspaper, and said he would call upon me again before he would leave the City— The weather has become so warm that for two days I have had no fire in my chamber. My wife continues recovering very slowly. My Son John has a bad cough, and declined General Macomb’s invitation to dinner

22. IV. Friday.— I occupied the whole day, to lose no time, but the effects of it upon my eye were severely felt. I cannot persevere, and must relax— John A. Smith was here, and took leave, going to New-York— Julia de Wint, returns home with him. I answered five of the Letters which have been accumulating upon my hands, for two months, unanswered— Called at the Pension Office, and gave a certificate that Elisha James was living at the time of the passage of the Act of 7. June 1832. I told Mr Edwards, that I had written to General Donnison at Boston, advising him to forward another set of Papers; those which he had forwarded before having been mislaid. Edwards afterwards informed me by a note, that the first set had been found; which I immediately wrote to General Donnison. Walk round the Capitol hill, before dinner. The Spring weather continues. I had projected employment for this Evening; but received the proof sheets of the Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures, from the Office of the Printer for Congress— I revised nearly half of it, until I found myself sleeping over the work. Received a Letter from Mr Samuel L. Southard.
23. V. Saturday

Morning visits from Mr Huygens, the Chargé d’Affaires from the king of Holland—and from Mr Rush— Huygens told me that his father was now at Copenhagen, where he had been minister from the Batavian Republic, many years. We conversed upon European Affairs, and the great defeat of the Turkish Sultan’s army, by Ibrahim the Son of the Bashaw of Egypt— I told Huygens I hoped Constantinople would soon become a European and a Christian City, and that the Religion of Mahomet would become extinct like the Paganism of the Greeks, and Romans— The imposture of Mahomet, and the influence it has exercised over the opinions and the history of mankind, are among the impenetrable mysteries of Providence— Mr Rush said he had nearly completed the sale of his House, and should return home next week— He has had one or more interviews with Mr Van Buren, which may possibly have some influence on his future
political opinions and conduct. I returned the visits of Mr Van Buren, and his Son, by Cards— Went to judge Cranch’s house, where I acknowledged a Deed from the Executors of Ward N. Boylston to Daniel T. Brigham, Isaac Davis and Perley Goddard, of Lands in Princeton; but afterwards thinking it imperfect, I enclosed it to my Son Charles. I completed the revisal of the Report of the Committee of Manufactures (that is of the Minority) printed as a Congressional Document; but have not been able to dispose of my time these three days, as I had predetermined— I see by an extract from the Hingham Gazette in the Boston Press this day received, that my Election to Congress will be opposed on the ground of anti-masonry.
24. IV:30. Sunday

Heard Mr Smith at the Presbyterian Church this morning— A fifth Sermon upon Romans 8.7. the carnal mind enmity against God— The special subject of this day’s Discourse, was the danger, of enmity against God. He gave notice that he should be absent next Sunday, but hoped to return before the Sunday after, and then to conclude the Series, of Sermons upon enmity against God, by urging the necessity of repentance— After the morning service, I had a visit from Mr Hassler, who is engaged upon a Survey of the Coast, under an act of Congress of the Session before the last, but who is in trouble by difficulties with the Secretary of the Treasury— I promised to speak with him on the subject. I did not exactly understand what the difficulty was; for though he is a very skilful mathematician and talks much, he has not the talent of giving a lucid exposition of his thoughts. After dinner, I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for the fifth Sunday in Lent, and for Sermon gave an exposition of the 91st Psalm. I took my Grand-child Mary-Louisa to church with me, Morning and afternoon— An inflammation in my right eye disabled me, for writing or reading, great part of this day, and the whole of the Evening. The National Gazette, and New-York American have republished the Minority Report.
25. IV:30. Monday

Mrs Tudor was here this morning, and mentioned that Mr. Michael Hogan, heretofore Consul at the Havana, and afterwards at Valparaiso in Chili, was in this city, at the point of Death, and she asked me to call and see him— Mr T. B. Johnson called to visit his Sister. I went to the National Intelligencer Office, and looked over the Newspapers; seventy or eighty of them received within the last two days. I walked round the Capitol hill— Answered a Letter received two months since from Henry Middleton— I meant to write six lines to thank him for the Platina coins which he sent me, and wrote three pages upon Nullification and Protection. In the Evening I went to Mrs Corcorans and enquired for Mr Hogan Mrs Corcoran told me that Mrs Hogan had directed that no person should be admitted to see him, as he was very low, and they believed him to be dying— I received a Letter from my Son Charles: who speaks of the opposition threatened by the Masons of Plymouth and Norfolk Counties to my election; and also of the Minority Report. Charles’s health and Spirits are indifferent, and his child has taken the whooping cough. The Advocate is the only paper in Boston, which publishes the whole Report— The rest give extracts— It is also republished in the Advocate of New-York. The Southern Papers do not notice its existence.

26. IV:15. Tuesday— The inflammation of my right eye has partly subsided, and I spent a great part of this day in writing. I had received yesterday a Letter from my Son Charles, to which I began this morning an answer; which I intended should be very short; but the pen ran on, till the time came for my walk round the Capitol hill— On my return from that, I received a packet from James L Edwards, Commissioner of the Pension Office, enclosing Certificates of Pensions for General William Donnison of Boston, and Elisha James of Scituate. I wrote immediately
to General Donnison, and to the Revd. Samuel Deane, enclosing to them the respective certificates— I had received early in January a Letter from Mr Deane concerning the claim of James— Both the Letters, with one to Henry Middleton, were sent this Evening to the Post Office. Mrs Adams rode out twice this day. The Essex Register has a commendatory notice of the minority Report, with extracts of the same character from Walsh’s National Gazette and from Stone’s Commercial Advertiser— They all republish it entire. The Essex Register in parcels of two or three Columns at a time. I received also a Letter from Samuel L. Gouverneur, respecting certain notices and a Letter of mine which he has found among the Papers of Mr Monroe— He offers to send me the Letters.

27. IV:30. Wednesday.— Early rising; and for two hours copying William L. Stone’s Masonic Manuscript; in which are many very curious varieties, from the common newly divulged revelations of Masonry— I received a Letter from John Bailey, and a Committee of an Antimasonic Convention, which met at Hanover last Thursday, and nominated me for re-election to the 23d. Congress— But in the Hingham Gazette, there is a Notification for a National Republican Convention at Scituate to-morrow; and a formal Address to the People of the District opposing my election upon the ground of anti-masonry, and particularly my Letter to Benjamin Cowell— I received also a Letter from a Committee of the young Men’s Convention at Harrisburg Pennsylvania, with a copy of a commendatory Resolution adopted by them in honour of R. Rush and of me. I went to the general Post-Office, upon several applications for Post-Offices— The Postmaster General was absent, at Alexandria. I saw the Assistants C. K. Gardiner, and afterwards Selah R. Hobbie— He told me the Post-Office for the South Parish of Hingham, should immediately be established. I left with him the Letter, from the Postmaster of North Scituate, Merritt; and the Letter from Christopher Slocom of Medway. Both of which relate to unsettled controversies of some standing, and which cannot soon be adjusted. Mary dined at her Uncle Johnson’s. Snow great part of the day.
28. IV:30. Thursday.

I answered the Letter of John Bailey, and the Committee of the Convention of Antimasons at Hanover, and the Letter from the Committee of the Committee of the Convention of Anti Masonic young men at Harrisburg Pennsylvania, and I wrote to Mr Enoch Reynolds, Treasurer of the Columbia College, a short note, to which I received an answer. Coll. Brearley came and introduced to me a Roman Catholic Clergyman from Brookline, on Long Island, opposite to the City of New York. He came to solicit a subscription for a Church which they are building there, and which from mere inability I was obliged to decline. I walked round the Capitol hill, before dinner— The day was chilly and raw. Snow-like, but without Snow— We are getting sickly again. My Son John has a severe cough, and his wife was all this day quite unwell— I am endeavouring to read, and have got to the tenth Canto of Rose’s Translation of Ariosto— I cannot take interest in it— Even the humour of the original evaporates in the Translation— For variety I read one Act of Byron’s Tragedy of the two Foscari. And the first thing I meet is a man under Torture— What Pleasure is there in the minute description of human agonies? Read also a Review of the Life of Schiller in the American Quarterly.
29. V:45. Friday.

In my walk this morning, I stop’d at the Capitol, at the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives to enquire for the printed Documents of the last Session of Congress. The Bank Reports of the Committee of Ways and Means, the Minority Report of the Committee of Manufactures, the Laws of the Session, and the returns of Manufactures of the preceding Session— None of them were ready— Mr Clarke spoke of the compilation of Documents relating to the History of this Country, prior to the establishment of the present Constitution. He
said he was going shortly to collect materials for it— As I was returning home, I met at the door of Mrs Strother’s house a man named Andrew Wallace, who was coming to see me, and came— He said he was one hundred and three years of age, the 26th. of this month. A Scot, born, descended from Robert, a brother of Sir William Wallace.— He was at the Battles of Preston Pans and Culloden, a Soldier of Prince Charles Edward, whom, as well as the Duke of Cumberland he well remembers.— After the Battle of Culloden, he fled first to Ireland, and thence in 1752. to this Country— Served in our army from 1776 till it was disbanded—re-inlisted in 1786 and continued as a Sergeant-Major in the army till 1813— Then discharged at the age of 83. Has since been a teacher till his strength failed— Lives at West-Chester, Pennsylvania, and comes here now to solicit an increase of Pension. His eye-sight, hearing and Memory seem unimpaired. What a life, and survival of chances! I had also a visit this Evening from P. R. Fendall—

30. IV:30. Saturday. Finished the copy of W. L. Stone’s first Masonic Manuscript. I received Letters from Zaccheus Bartlett, and John B. Thomas of Plymouth, with applications for Revolutionary Pensioners, with which, I immediately called upon the Secretary of War. He took down all their names, and promised that immediate attention should be paid to their cases. I asked him also for copies of the papers in the Department relating to the application from Lieutt. Governor Pitcher of New-York, for the arrest of Coll. William King in the Arkansas Territory, which he promised me. He shewed me an original Letter from Major Washington to Genl. Forbes dated in October 1758. containing a plan of Campaign against the Indians— Cass said it was the same plan which we had recently carried into execution. I went also to the Navy-Office, and enquired of Mr Woodbury the Secretary for the residence of George Beale, a prize Agent, who has credit for the payment of Liliston Banks’s prize money. He indicated to me Beale’s residence, just beyond the borders of the City— I rode there after dinner with the Ladies, and found Mr Beale, who is a purser in the Navy, laid up with the rhumatism— I gave him Mr Z. Bartlett’s Letter to him (which was unsigned) and he promised to answer the enquiries to-morrow. In the evening I was answering a Letter from N. Biddle, respecting the Girard College— Not finished.
31. IV:30. Sunday. United States Treasury Department building, burnt down.

The public building of the Treasury Department, took fire about two O’Clock this morning, and was in ruin by the dawn of day— I went out and viewed it between four and five, when the fire was abating by the failure of combustible materials. I found William C. Greenleaf there, and met Mr Clarke, Clerk of the House of Representatives— Heard at the Presbyterian Church, Mr J. S. Skinner from 2. Corinthians 5.17. “Therefore, if any man be in Christ he is a new creature: old things are passed away: behold, all things are become new.”— Regeneration, and something about the conflagration of the Treasury— Mr Skinner gave notice, that he was engaged elsewhere this afternoon, and that there would be no service at that Church. I went to St. John’s, where Mr Hawley read the evening prayer, for the Sunday before Easter, or Palm-Sunday, and preached a short Discourse, from Matthew 26.8. “Then saith he unto them, my Soul is exceeding sorrowful even unto Death.”— There was no organist, and no singing. John’s child Louisa, went with me, morning and afternoon— I received several Letters among which one from my Son Charles, with a new Deed to execute instead of that which I had sent back to him— I wrote a long Letter to N. Biddle, which I burnt, and then wrote a short one. Received another Letter from Zaccheus Bartlett and two copies of the Minority Report Boston Edition.

Memm. 26. July 1835— On the 10th. of January 1833 my Diary in this volume, was suspended by sickness, but I continued it upon loose sheets of paper, from which I have been from the 1st. instt. transcribing it.
